intro: Cypella herbertii subsp. wolffhuegelii, commonly known as the Woolly Cypella, is a perennial herb native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and small, inconspicuous white flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands or along stream banks. Its botanical features include a creeping rhizome and a compact rosette of foliage. It is relatively drought-tolerant once established, making it adaptable to various environmental conditions.
